subject: RE: [junit] Dynamically generating test methods?
msgSnippet: Ok, I ve tried your approach.  Now I m getting a ConcurrentModificationException when I run my test. My suite() method is as follows: public static Test
messageBody:
Ok, I've tried your approach. Now I'm getting a
ConcurrentModificationException when I run my test.

My suite() method is as follows:

public static Test suite() {
String request = null;
String control = null;
org.jdom.Element file = null;
String expr = null;
Iterator xpaths = null;
Vector nodelistExpressions = new Vector();
Vector valueExpressions = new Vector();

TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
readTestScript();
while (files.hasNext()) {
file = (org.jdom.Element) files.next();
request = loadRequestFile(file);
control = loadControlFile(file);

xpaths = file.getChildren().iterator();
while (xpaths.hasNext()) {
// build 2 vectors depending on the xpath expression
}
suite.addTest(new
TestXmlBatchMaintenance("testXpathXmlSubmission",
request,
control,
requestHandler,

nodelistExpressions.iterator(),

valueExpressions.iterator()));

}
return suite;

The "testXpathXmlSubmission" is the name of the method in the TestCase that
actually runs the test. It looks like this:

public void testXpathXmlSubmission() {
String result = null;
String expr = null;
try {
//Submit request file to application
result = submitQxml(request);

while (nodelistExpressions.hasNext()) {
expr = (String) nodelistExpressions.next();
//ConcurrentModificationException pops up here
assertXpathsEqual(expr, control, expr, result);
}
while (valueExpressions.hasNext()) {
expr = (String) valueExpressions.next();
assertXpathValuesEqual(expr, control, expr, result);
}
} catch (Exception e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}
}

Thanks for the help!


-dmg




-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 04, 2003 3:27 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Dynamically generating test methods?


The JUnit framework is not treating your tests as a single test; you
are. :) Just code your TestSuite to add a TestCase instance for each
<file> element.

suite() {
suite = new TestSuite();
dom = makeDomFrom("xml_testing.xml");
fileNodes = dom.getNodeList(... "/file");
for each node in fileNodes {
suite.addTest(new MyTestCase(new File(node.getFileName()),
node.getExpectedXpathExpressions()))
}
return suite;
}

Add constructor:

TestCase(file, xpathExpressions) {
super(file.getName());
set expected xpath expressions
}

That ought to do it.

Remember folks: you can add constructors! :)

Good luck.


So said David Goudreau on 2003-02-04 --------------------

>I'm creating a framework to test XML responses to our system. Right
now I
>have a properties file that contains 1) every file request I want to
send
>to
>our system and 2) the xpath expressions I want to run on the XML
response,
>to make sure it's correct. The properties file looks like this:
>
><xml_testing controldir="controlxml" requestdir="requestxml">
> <file name="test1.xml">
> <xpath expression="//FUNCTION/RESPONSE_DATA"/>
> <xpath expression="//USER"/>
> </file>
> <file name="test2.xml">
> <xpath expression="//HEADER/IP_ADDRESS"/>
> </file>
> <file name="test3.xml">
> <xpath expression="//USER/NAME"/>
> <xpath expression="//USER/ADDRESS"/>
> </file>
></xml_testing>
>
>The problem I'm having is that I want each <file> to run as a separate
test
>in the JUnit framework. Right now, even if I have 100 files that I
want to
>test in my properties file, the JUnit framework treats it all as one
test.
>I don't want test #4 to fail and then prevent the other 96 tests from
>running, which is what's happening now. Any ideas? Thanks.
>
>
